**Gareth Southgate** (born 3 September 1970) is an English
[football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") manager and
former player who played as a
[defender](/wiki/Defender_\(association_football\) "Defender \(association
football\)") or as a [midfielder](/wiki/Midfielder "Midfielder"). He is the
manager of the [England national team](/wiki/England_national_football_team
"England national football team").

He won the [League Cup](/wiki/Football_League_Cup "Football League Cup") with
both [Aston Villa](/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C. "Aston Villa F.C.") and
[Middlesbrough](/wiki/Middlesbrough_F.C. "Middlesbrough F.C.") (in
[1995–96](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_Football_League_Cup "1995–96 Football League
Cup") and [2003–04](/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_Football_League_Cup "2003–04
Football League Cup") respectively), and captained [Crystal
Palace](/wiki/Crystal_Palace_F.C. "Crystal Palace F.C.") to win the [First
Division](/wiki/Football_League_Division_One "Football League Division One")
championship in [1993–94](/wiki/1993%E2%80%9394_Football_League "1993–94
Football League"). He also played in the [2000 FA Cup
Final](/wiki/2000_FA_Cup_Final "2000 FA Cup Final") for Villa and the [2006
UEFA Cup Final](/wiki/2006_UEFA_Cup_Final "2006 UEFA Cup Final") for
Middlesbrough. Internationally, Southgate made 57 appearances for the England
national team between 1995 and 2004, featuring in the [1998 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World Cup") and both the
[1996](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1996 "UEFA Euro 1996") and [2000 European
Championships](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2000 "UEFA Euro 2000"). His playing career
ended in May 2006 at the age of 35, and after more than 500 league
appearances.

He served as manager of Middlesbrough from June 2006 until October 2009,
managed the [England U21 team](/wiki/England_national_under-21_football_team
"England national under-21 football team") from 2013 to 2016, before becoming
the England national team manager in 2016.

## Club
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Club career")]

### Crystal
Palace[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Crystal Palace")]

Born in [Watford](/wiki/Watford "Watford"), Hertfordshire,[4] Southgate began
his career at [Crystal Palace](/wiki/Crystal_Palace_F.C. "Crystal Palace
F.C."), playing initially at [right-
back](/wiki/Defender_\(association_football\)#Full-back "Defender
\(association football\)") and then in central [midfield](/wiki/Midfielder
"Midfielder"). He became [captain](/wiki/Captain_\(association_football\)
"Captain \(association football\)") and led the club to the [1993–94 First
Division](/wiki/1993-94_in_English_football "1993-94 in English football")
title. After the South London club's relegation from the [Premier
League](/wiki/Premier_League "Premier League"), he moved to [Aston
Villa](/wiki/Aston_Villa_F.C. "Aston Villa F.C.") for a fee of £2.5 million,
having made 152 appearances over four seasons.

His nickname at Palace was 'Nord', given him because his precise way of
speaking reminded one of the coaches of [Denis Norden](/wiki/Denis_Norden
"Denis Norden")'s vocal delivery.[5]

### Aston
Villa[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Aston Villa")]

At Aston Villa, he was converted into a [centre-
back](/wiki/Defender_\(association_football\) "Defender \(association
football\)") and was part of a formidable defence. In his first season, he
lifted the [League Cup](/wiki/Football_League_Cup "Football League Cup") and
Aston Villa qualified for the [UEFA Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup "UEFA Cup"). Southgate
played in every Premier League game during the 1998–99 season. He continued to
play for Villa in the 1999–2000 season as Villa reached the [FA Cup
Final](/wiki/2000_FA_Cup_Final "2000 FA Cup Final"), but handed in a transfer
request just before [Euro 2000](/wiki/Euro_2000 "Euro 2000"), claiming that
"if I am to achieve in my career, it is time to move on."[6]

###
Middlesbrough[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Middlesbrough")]

On 11 July 2001, Southgate signed for [Middlesbrough](/wiki/Middlesbrough_F.C.
"Middlesbrough F.C.") for a £6.5 million fee. He joined on a four-year deal
and was the first signing by [Steve McClaren](/wiki/Steve_McClaren "Steve
McClaren"), whom he knew as an England coach.[7][8]

In July 2002, after [Paul Ince](/wiki/Paul_Ince "Paul Ince") left for
[Wolverhampton Wanderers](/wiki/Wolverhampton_Wanderers_F.C. "Wolverhampton
Wanderers F.C."), Southgate was appointed the new Middlesbrough captain. On 29
February 2004, he became the first Boro skipper in their 128-year history to
lift a trophy, as they defeated [Bolton Wanderers](/wiki/Bolton_Wanderers_F.C.
"Bolton Wanderers F.C.") in the [2004 Football League Cup
Final](/wiki/2004_Football_League_Cup_Final "2004 Football League Cup Final")
at the [Millennium Stadium](/wiki/Millennium_Stadium "Millennium Stadium").[9]

Southgate rejected media rumours that he was set to move to [Manchester
United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.") following [Rio
Ferdinand](/wiki/Rio_Ferdinand "Rio Ferdinand")'s ban for missing a drug test
in January 2004.[10] He later committed his final playing years to
Middlesbrough, signing until 2007. His final appearance as a professional
player was in the [2006 UEFA Cup Final](/wiki/2006_UEFA_Cup_Final "2006 UEFA
Cup Final") against [Sevilla](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla FC"), which Boro lost
4–0 at the [Philips Stadion](/wiki/Philips_Stadion "Philips Stadion") in
[Eindhoven](/wiki/Eindhoven "Eindhoven").[9]

## International
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: International career")]

Southgate made his debut for [England](/wiki/England_national_football_team
"England national football team") as a substitute against
[Portugal](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team "Portugal national football
team") in December 1995 under the management of [Terry
Venables](/wiki/Terry_Venables "Terry Venables").[11] Southgate played every
minute of their matches as hosts England reached the semi-final of [UEFA Euro
1996](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1996 "UEFA Euro 1996"), in which they faced
[Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football
team"). The match was determined in a [penalty shoot-
out](/wiki/Penalty_shootout "Penalty shootout"); Southgate's penalty was
saved, and England were eliminated.[12] The song "Southgate (Euro '96)" by
[The Business](/wiki/The_Business_\(band\) "The Business \(band\)") is a
reference to this event. Southgate managed to make light of his blunder later
that year by appearing in an advert for [Pizza Hut](/wiki/Pizza_Hut "Pizza
Hut"), also featuring [Stuart Pearce](/wiki/Stuart_Pearce "Stuart Pearce") and
[Chris Waddle](/wiki/Chris_Waddle "Chris Waddle"), who had missed crucial
penalties at the [1990 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup "1990 FIFA
World Cup").[13]

Southgate also played in the [1998 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup
"1998 FIFA World Cup") and [UEFA Euro 2000](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2000 "UEFA Euro
2000").[14] His 50th cap came in a 1–1 draw with Portugal at [Villa
Park](/wiki/Villa_Park "Villa Park") in September 2002.[11] On 11 June 2003,
he played the full 90 minutes in a 2–1 Euro 2004 qualifying win over
[Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia_national_football_team "Slovakia national football
team") at his club ground of the [Riverside Stadium](/wiki/Riverside_Stadium
"Riverside Stadium"), competing against Middlesbrough's striker [Szilárd
Németh](/wiki/Szil%C3%A1rd_N%C3%A9meth "Szilárd Németh").[15]

Southgate was [capped](/wiki/Cap_\(sport\)#Association_football "Cap
\(sport\)") 57 times for England and scored twice.[11] His first goal came on
14 October 1998 against [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg_national_football_team
"Luxembourg national football team") in a Euro 2000 qualifier, his second on
22 May 2003 against [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa_national_football_team
"South Africa national football team") in a friendly.[11] He is Aston Villa's
most capped England player, having played 42 of his 57 internationals whilst
with Villa.[16]

## Management
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Management career")]

###
Middlesbrough[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=7&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Middlesbrough")]

Southgate was handed his first managerial role at Middlesbrough in June 2006
after Steve McClaren had left to manage England. His appointment drew
controversy as he did not have the required coaching qualifications (the [UEFA
Pro Licence](/wiki/UEFA_Pro_Licence "UEFA Pro Licence")) to manage a top-
flight club.[17] He was allowed to stay on as manager, however, by the Premier
League in November 2006; Middlesbrough successfully argued that, because
Southgate had recently been an international player, he had no opportunity to
undertake the coaching courses.[18] He did go on to complete his coaching
qualifications.[19]

In his first season in charge, Southgate guided Middlesbrough to 12th position
in the Premier League. His biggest win as a manager was an 8–1 victory against
[Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C.") in May
2008. In December 2007, [Arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal_F.C. "Arsenal F.C.") manager
[Arsène Wenger](/wiki/Ars%C3%A8ne_Wenger "Arsène Wenger") suggested Southgate
as one of several English managers who were "all good enough" to manage the
national team.[20] He faced some criticism early in the 2007–08 season after
Boro had a spell in the relegation zone, but they later pulled clear of the
bottom three.[21]

In November 2008, Southgate took Middlesbrough up to 8th place after an away
win against on-form Aston Villa; however, Boro would thereafter go 14 games
without a win, finally defeating Liverpool at home 2–0 on 28 February
2009.[22] After an away defeat against [Stoke City](/wiki/Stoke_City "Stoke
City"), some of the travelling supporters were calling for his dismissal after
only achieving one win in 18 games and relegation survival looking unlikely.
On 24 March, chairman [Steve Gibson](/wiki/Steve_Gibson_\(businessman\) "Steve
Gibson \(businessman\)") announced that sacking Southgate would not "help the
situation".[23] Middlesbrough finished in 19th position and were relegated to
[the Championship](/wiki/Football_League_Championship "Football League
Championship") after a 2–1 defeat at [West Ham United](/wiki/West_Ham_United
"West Ham United").[24] Southgate said he was determined to get the club back
into the Premier League, praised the supporters and said that he felt for
them.[25]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Gareth_Southgate_18-05-2013_1.jpg/170px-
Gareth_Southgate_18-05-2013_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gareth_Southgate_18-05-2013_1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gareth_Southgate_18-05-2013_1.jpg "Enlarge")

Southgate in 2013

On 20 October 2009, shortly after a 2–0 victory over [Derby
County](/wiki/Derby_County_F.C. "Derby County F.C."), Southgate was dismissed
as manager with Middlesbrough in fourth place in the Championship. The
dismissal was controversial as he had taken Boro to within one point of the
top position,[26][27] but Gibson said he had made the decision weeks earlier
in the best interests of the club.[28]

###
England[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=8&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: England")]

#### 2013–2016: Under-21
team[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=9&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 2013–2016: Under-21 team")]

In August 2013, Southgate was named manager of the [England under-21
team](/wiki/England_national_under-21_football_team "England national under-21
football team"), signing a three-year contract.[29] In his first game in
charge, they beat [Moldova](/wiki/Moldova_national_under-21_football_team
"Moldova national under-21 football team") 1–0 in a [European Championships
qualifier](/wiki/2015_UEFA_European_Under-21_Football_Championship_qualification
"2015 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification") thanks to a
goal from [Saido Berahino](/wiki/Saido_Berahino "Saido Berahino").[30] Under
Southgate England qualified for the finals of the [European Under-21
Championship](/wiki/2015_UEFA_European_Under-21_Championship "2015 UEFA
European Under-21 Championship") in 2015, where they were knocked out in the
group stages, finishing last in their group.

#### 2016–present: Senior
team[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=10&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 2016–present: Senior team")]

##### Caretaker
spell[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=11&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Caretaker spell")]

Southgate was put in temporary charge of the senior England team on 27
September 2016, when [Sam Allardyce](/wiki/Sam_Allardyce "Sam Allardyce")
resigned after one game due to the [2016 English football
scandal](/wiki/2016_English_football_scandal "2016 English football
scandal").[31] England were in the early stages of [qualifying for the 2018
FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(UEFA\) "2018 FIFA
World Cup qualification \(UEFA\)"). After winning his first game in charge 2–0
against [Malta](/wiki/Malta_national_football_team "Malta national football
team"),[32] under Southgate's leadership, England went on to draw 0–0 with
[Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia_national_football_team "Slovenia national football
team"),[33] beat [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team "Scotland
national football team") 3–0,[34] and in his last game in temporary charge,
drew 2–2 with [Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team"), despite leading 2–0 and conceding goals in the 89th and 96th
minutes.[35] Southgate's spell as caretaker manager ended on 15 November.[36]

On 30 November 2016, Southgate was appointed as England manager on a four-year
contract.[37]

##### 2018 FIFA World
Cup[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=12&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 2018 FIFA World Cup")]

The England team qualified for the [2018 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") on 5 October 2017, with
a 1–0 home win over [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia_national_football_team "Slovenia
national football team").[38]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Gareth_Southgate.jpg/170px-
Gareth_Southgate.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gareth_Southgate.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gareth_Southgate.jpg "Enlarge")

Southgate with [England](/wiki/England_national_football_team "England
national football team") at the [2018 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup")

After wins against [Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia_national_football_team "Tunisia
national football team") and [Panama](/wiki/Panama_national_football_team
"Panama national football team") saw England qualify behind
[Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team "Belgium national football
team") in their [2018 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA
World Cup") group, Southgate's England side beat
[Colombia](/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team "Colombia national football
team") 4–3 on [penalties](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\)
"Penalty shoot-out \(association football\)") in the round of 16 after a 1–1
draw on 3 July 2018 to claim his nation's first ever World Cup penalty shoot-
out victory and a place in the quarter-final.[39] On 7 July 2018, Southgate's
England side beat [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team "Sweden
national football team") in a 2–0 win in the 2018 FIFA World Cup quarter
finals, with Southgate becoming the first England manager to reach the semi-
finals of the World Cup since [Sir Bobby Robson](/wiki/Sir_Bobby_Robson "Sir
Bobby Robson")'s side at the [1990 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup
"1990 FIFA World Cup").[40] This success bought Southgate significant
admiration from England fans.[41] For the semi-final with
[Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia national football
team"), fans dressed up in [waistcoats](/wiki/Waistcoat "Waistcoat") in
tribute to Southgate's iconic waistcoat, which he wore during England's
matches: retailer [Marks & Spencer](/wiki/Marks_%26_Spencer "Marks & Spencer")
reported a 35% increase in sales of waistcoats,[42][43][44] and the hashtag
'WaistcoatWednesday' trended on [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter").[44][45] A
week after the end of the tournament, [Southgate tube
station](/wiki/Southgate_tube_station "Southgate tube station") in
[Enfield](/wiki/London_Borough_of_Enfield "London Borough of Enfield"),
[London](/wiki/London "London"), was renamed to "Gareth Southgate" for two
days in recognition of Southgate's achievement.[46][47] Southgate was also
lauded for personal qualities shown in the World Cup, including consoling an
opposition player whose missed penalty had seen England win.[48]

On 11 July 2018, Southgate's England side suffered a 2–1 defeat to Croatia
after extra time in the semi-finals of the [2018 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup"). [Kieran
Trippier](/wiki/Kieran_Trippier "Kieran Trippier") opened the scoring for
England with a free kick, before a goal from [Ivan
Perišić](/wiki/Ivan_Peri%C5%A1i%C4%87 "Ivan Perišić") sent the tie into extra
time. [Mario Mandžukić](/wiki/Mario_Mand%C5%BEuki%C4%87 "Mario Mandžukić")
scored the winner for [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia
national football team") in the second half of extra time. With England
trailing, the match also saw England play the final ten minutes of extra time
with ten men as Trippier suffered an injury after Southgate had already made
his permitted substitutions.[49] Following a 2-0 defeat to Belgium in the
third place play-off, England ended the World Cup in fourth place.[50] [Harry
Kane](/wiki/Harry_Kane "Harry Kane"), a striker and the England team captain,
also won the [Golden Boot](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Boot "FIFA World
Cup awards") as the tournament's top goal-scorer.[47]

## Other
roles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=13&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Other roles")]

In 2003, Southgate and close friend and current Crystal Palace goalkeeping
coach [Andy Woodman](/wiki/Andy_Woodman "Andy Woodman") co-wrote _Woody &
Nord: A Football Friendship_. This book describes an enduring friendship
forged in the Crystal Palace youth team that has survived Southgate and
Woodman's wildly differing fortunes in the professional game. The book won the
Sports Book of the Year award for 2004 from the [National Sporting
Club](/wiki/National_Sporting_Club "National Sporting Club") (now the [British
Sports Book Awards](/wiki/British_Sports_Book_Awards "British Sports Book
Awards")).[51][52]

Southgate was also a co-commentator for ITV at the 2006 World Cup, covering
group games alongside [Clive Tyldesley](/wiki/Clive_Tyldesley "Clive
Tyldesley").[53] His appointment as Middlesbrough manager two days before the
start of the tournament meant that he left Germany before the knockout phase
began, with [David Pleat](/wiki/David_Pleat "David Pleat") replacing him as
Tyldesley's co-commentator.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] He resumed a role as
[pundit](/wiki/Pundit_\(expert\) "Pundit \(expert\)") and co-commentator after
he finished his tenure at Middlesbrough in 2010, working on [FA
Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup") and [UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") matches for
[ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)") as well as acting as a
pundit on England games.[54][55]

In January 2011, Southgate was appointed as the FA's head of elite
development, to work with Sir [Trevor Brooking](/wiki/Trevor_Brooking "Trevor
Brooking").[56] He left the post in July 2012, and ruled himself out of
consideration for the role of technical director,[57] for which he had been a
leading candidate.[58]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gareth_Southgate&action=edit&section=14&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Southgate attended [Hazelwick School](/wiki/Hazelwick_School "Hazelwick
School") in [Crawley](/wiki/Crawley "Crawley"), West Sussex. Southgate is
married to Alison; the couple have two children.[59]
